awd_titl_txt: iUTAH-innovative Urban Transitions and Aridregion Hydro-sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Infrastructure Improvement (RII) Track-1 award considers one of the most important problems facing the Western US, the problem of current (and future) water provision under climate change coupled with increasing urbanization and demand for water. The proposal focuses on the interactions between climate change, water rights issues and water availability within Utah. The research examines the fundamental interactions and dynamic feedbacks among hydroclimate and the ecological and human aspects of urban and montane landscapes. The project brings together research universities, colleges, business, government and the residents of Utah to address key issues related to ecosystems research, education, and workforce development in the state.

Intellectual Merit
This RII project targets the issue of water supply and management under future climate change within Utah. iUTAH builds the human capital, data, and supporting infrastructure to tackle this demanding task. Integrated, multi-disciplinary research teams will be created to identify how physical systems and human systems interact together to affect water supply, demand and management. Investments in instrumentation, data collection and professional expertise, support the modeling of alternative water futures for Utah; and the development of water management, conservation and treatment technologies.
The integration of physical observational data and social science survey data and models will lead efforts to inform policy makers, resource managers and the citizenry of Utah about possible water futures. Visualization tools and citizen engagement will be used to create two way feedbacks between researchers and other groups. This research will help to identify future vulnerabilities and adaptation technologies related to water provision in a rapidly growing state.

Broader Impacts
iUTAH develops a full suite of formal and informal educational activities to engage a wide number of constituents. Activities span K-12 students and teachers; undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty; citizen science and industry and federal government. Efforts are geographically broad and recognize rural and urban participation. There is broad engagement of many underrepresented groups in STEM such as women, Native Americans and Hispanic populations. The iUTAH team is partnering with two museums and citizen science programs. There is significant interaction between research and education and the activities directly strengthen areas noted as important within the state Science and Technology Plan.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The iUTAH EPSCoR project ran from 2012-2018, and was a statewide effort aimed to build Utah’s research capacity to understand and enhance Utah’s water resources. To enhance research capacity, the project aimed to increase inter-campus collaboration and stakeholder engagement in water-related research.  A total of 817 participants engaged in research, education, and outreach activities sponsored by the project. Participation in the iUTAH project increased research outputs (publications and citation rates) compared to non-participants and markedly increased co-authoring among researchers across disciplines and organizations. Participants published 167 peer reviewed articles and received new external research awards for a project total of nearly $30M.  Important research findings showed that natural and human-modified watersheds respond similarly to climate change, challenging the long-held assumption that reservoirs and diversions mask climate-induced changes to stream flow.  Despite being in an arid climate with limited water supply and rapid population growth, Utah water managers’ perception of water resource vulnerability to scarcity were diffuse or misaligned with supply projections.  iUTAH’s cyberinfrastructure team pioneered in the field of hydroinformatics by developing new software tools for storing, managing, visualizing, and analyzing data streams from automated environmental sensor networks and social science surveys, and by developing new model coupling platforms to represent human-natural system interactions. Broader impacts of the project included enhanced engagement between stakeholders and researchers that influenced water resource decision making.  For example, the city of Riverton used iUTAH household survey data as the impetus to change water supply and build new water storage; and the Utah Division of Water Quality partnered with iUTAH researchers to aim hydrologic observatory infrastructure to better predict harmful algal blooms.  iUTAH’s education, outreach, and diversity platform contributed to an enhanced STEM workforce in the state by engaging 272 undergraduates in the research enterprise.  Of those who have completed their degree programs, many went on to graduate/professional schools or are employed in STEM-related fields in water resources, tourism, and software development.

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2018
Modified by: Michelle A Baker
